Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: A journal submission deadline is imminent and requires the finalized report and datasets.
Story: I sat on the edge of the bed, laptop open, fingers hovering over the keyboard. The cursor blinked accusingly on the half-finished results section, the journal’s submission portal open in another tab, the deadline just hours away. From the living room, I heard muffled sobs—my partner, curled up on the couch, lost in grief after the sudden loss of his father. I knew he needed me, needed my arms around him, my words, my presence. But the data sets on my screen demanded my attention, every detail needing to be checked, every sentence crafted with precision. My mind raced with statistical analyses and comforting words, guilt gnawing at me for even considering my work at a time like this. Yet, the thought of letting down my research team, of missing the deadline we’d all worked so hard for, made my chest tighten. I felt split in two, torn between the person I loved and the work I’d dedicated years to. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I sat frozen, unable to move toward either room.
